metadata.title: Enhanced high-temperature performance of Li-rich layered oxide via surface heterophase coating

Fig 1 Fig. 2 (a) XRD patterns of LRM, LRM-2, LRM-3 and LRM-4. “R” refers to the “R 3 ¯ m phase”, “C” refers to the “C2/m phase”; (b) Enlarged regions for the (003), (104) and (020) reflections taken from the corresponding powder XRD patterns in (a). Fig 2 Fig. 3 SEM images of (a) LRM, (b) LRM-2, (c) LRM-3 and (d) LRM-4. Fig 3 Fig. 4 HRTEM images of (a) LRM-3, (b-d) selected region enlarged view of (a) and corresponding Fast Fourier Transformed (FFT) images; (e) EDX mappings of the Mn, Ni, O and P elements of LRM-3. Fig 4 Fig. 5 The XPS patterns of LRM, LRM-2, LRM-3 and LRM-4 samples: (a) Mn 2p 3/2 and (b) O 1s. Fig 5 Fig. 6 Initial charge/discharge curves of all samples in the voltage range 2.0–4.8 V at (a) 30 °C and (c) 55 °C; Cycling performance of all samples in the voltage range 2.0–4.6 V at 1 C under (b) 30 °C and (d) 55 °C; Selected charge/discharge potential profiles of the (e) LRM and (f) LRM-3 samples at 1 C. Fig 6 Fig. 7 (a) Average discharge voltage vs. cycle number of all samples; Normalized charge/discharge curves at 1 C under 55 °C of (b) LRM and (c) LRM-3. The capacity normalization was performed by taking the maximum capacity in the corresponding cycle as unity. Fig 7 Fig. 8 Differential capacity vs. voltage curves of different cycles at 1 C under 55 °C for (a) LRM and (b) LRM-3; Electrochemical impedance spectra of (c) LRM and (d) LRM-3. Fig 8 Fig. 9 HRTEM images of (a) LRM, (b) LRM-3 after 100 cycles at 1 C, (c–e) selected region enlarged view of (b) and corresponding FFT images. Fig 9 Enhanced high-temperature performance of Li-rich layered oxide via surface heterophase coating Yuefeng Su a b Feiyu Yuan a b Lai Chen a b ⁎ Yun Lu a b Jinyang Dong a b Youyou Fang a b Shi Chen a Feng Wu a b a Beijing Key Laboratory of Environmental Science and Engineering, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, China Beijing Key Laboratory of Environmental Science and Engineering School of Materials Science and Engineering Beijing Institute of Technology Beijing 100081 China aBeijing Key Laboratory of Environmental Science and Engineering, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, China b Beijing Institute of Technology Chongqing Innovation Center, Chongqing 401120, China Beijing Institute of Technology Chongqing Innovation Center Chongqing 401120 China bBeijing Institute of Technology Chongqing Innovation Center, Chongqing 401120, China ⁎ Corresponding author at: Beijing Key Laboratory of Environmental Science and Engineering, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, China. Beijing Key Laboratory of Environmental Science and Engineering School of Materials Science and Engineering Beijing Institute of Technology Beijing 100081 China Li-rich layered oxides have become one of the most concerned cathode materials for high-energy lithium-ion batteries, but they still suffer from poor cycling stability and detrimental voltage decay, especially at elevated temperature. Herein, we proposed a surface heterophase coating engineering based on amorphous/crystalline Li3PO4 to address these issues for Li-rich layered oxides via a facile wet chemical method. The heterophase coating layer combines the advantages of physical barrier effect achieved by amorphous Li3PO4 with facilitated Li+ diffusion stemmed from crystalline Li3PO4. Consequently, the modified Li1.2Ni0.2Mn0.6O2 delivers higher initial coulombic efficiency of 92% with enhanced cycling stability at 55 °C (192.9 mAh/g after 100 cycles at 1 C). More importantly, the intrinsic voltage decay has been inhibited as well, i.e. the average potential drop per cycle decreases from 5.96 mV to 2.99 mV. This surface heterophase coating engineering provides an effective strategy to enhance the high-temperature electrochemical performances of Li-rich layered oxides and guides the direction of surface modification strategies for cathode materials in the future. Graphical abstract The Li-rich layered Li1.2Ni0.2Mn0.6O2 cathode material has been successfully coated with heterophase amorphous/crystalline Li3PO4 layer, which greatly suppresses the voltage decay and capacity fading at elevated temperature. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Li-rich layered oxide Surface heterophase coating Crystalline/amorphous Li3PO4 High-temperature performance Voltage decay 1 Introduction Along with the rapid development of portable electronic devices, electric vehicles (EVs) and hybrid electric vehicles (HEVs), developing lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) with high energy density has become the research focus [1,2]. However, conventional cathode materials, such as LiCoO2, LiMn2O4, and LiFePO4, have low specific capacity, which makes them inadequate for constructing such high-energy LIBs [3,4]. In recent years, Li-rich layered oxides xLi2MnO3∙(1-x) LiMO2 (M = Mn, Ni, Co, etc.) have been the research hotspot in the field of cathode materials for next generation LIBs, because of their extremely high reversible discharge capacity (>250 mAh/g) [5–7]. Besides, this family of materials contain trace or no cobalt, giving them a competitive advantage in terms of cost. Whereas, several fundamental challenges still need to be settled for Li-rich layered oxides, such as low initial efficiency [8,9], severe voltage decay [10,11] and poor kinetics [12,13]. Among these technical challenges, the voltage decay issue that closely related to the transition metal migration during cycling has become the most intractable problem [14]. In particular, the voltage decay and energy density degradation will be accelerated when the LIBs are operated at high temperature (≥55 °C) [15]. Given that, the high temperature performance has been considered as a key criterion to evaluate the battery performance [16]. Thus, the aggravated voltage/capacity decays issue of Li-rich materials at elevated temperatures must be addressed before their large scale commercialization [17]. In the past few years, extensive researches and lots of effort have been demonstrated that surface modification is a convenient and effective method to solve the drawbacks of Li-rich oxides [18]. The most widely used coating materials are metal oxides [19–21], metal fluorides [22–24] and phosphates [25–27]. Among them, Li3PO4 has attracted a lot of attention due to its superior Li+ ionic conductivity, good chemical inertness and thermal stability [28]. For example, it has been explored that benefiting from the improved Li diffusivity and reduced dissolution of transition metal ions, the Li3PO4 coated Li-rich oxide achieved a better rate capability [29]. In addition, Li3PO4 protective layer has been also introduced successfully to stabilize the Li-rich oxides structure at elevated temperature of 60 °C [30]. However, such simply coating layer is easy to peel off from the surface of host materials, due to the polarization effect and volume change during repeated charging and discharging process [31]. Therefore, developing optimized surface coating engineering is urgent and considerable in giving full play to the role of Li3PO4-based modification strategies. In addition to the preparation process, the crystal phase of the introduced coating material also affects its effectiveness. Unlike the homogeneous structures with uniform phase state, the heterophase materials contain amorphous and crystalline states along with diverse physiochemical properties in optics, catalysis, and electronics [32–34]. Typically, the crystalline phase retains high ionic conductivity, owing to its less grain boundaries, long-range structure order and directional arrangement. Whereas, its applications in electrochemical research are still limited by poor retrievability of stress accumulation and lower chemical stability [35]. On the contrary, the amorphous phase with metastable structure, possesses higher chemical stability due to the reversible structure and higher porosity [36]. Consequently, it's expected that constructing a rational crystal-phase heterostructure coating layer with numerous hetero-interfaces may be a new and more efficient surface modification strategy for cathode materials. In this paper, we report an amorphous/crystalline surface coating engineering and investigate the synergetic effect of Li3PO4 heterophase coating layer on Li-rich cathode material at elevated temperature. Li1.2Ni0.2Mn0.6O2 is employed here as a representative cobalt-free Li-rich cathode for study. The Li3PO4 heterophase coating layer consists crystalline and amorphous Li3PO4. The crystalline Li3PO4 can provide fast lithium ion diffusion channels and PO4 3− has strong covalent bond with good thermal stability, which helps to restrain the transition metal ions migration and improve the structural stability of the Li-rich cathode at high temperature. On the other hand, the amorphous Li3PO4 can not only act as a protection layer to reduce the interfacial side reactions between the electrode and electrolyte, but also relieve the stress accumulation and tolerate volume changes during the long cycling. Benefiting from the synergistic effect of heterophase Li3PO4 coating layer, the electrochemical performances of the Li-rich material at elevated temperature have been significantly improved. The detailed explanations are discussed later. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of the pristine and Li3PO4-coated samples Sol-gel method was adopted to synthesize the pristine Li1.2Ni0.2Mn0.6O2 material. In order to obtain the Li3PO4-coated Li1.2Ni0.2Mn0.6O2 material, a certain amount of LiH2PO4 (2, 3 and 4 wt% relative to Li1.2Ni0.2Mn0.6O2 powder) was dissolved in a mixed solution of ethyl alcohol and distilled water with volume ratio 2:1 to form a transparent solution. The prepared Li1.2Ni0.2Mn0.6O2 particles were slowly poured into the LiH2PO4 solution. Then the mixed solution was evaporated at 60 °C with continuous stirring. At last, the powder was sintered at 450 °C for 5 h in air. The amorphous/crystalline heterophase Li3PO4 coating layer was successfully prepared after the thermal decomposition of LiH2PO4 precursor during the calcination process. The schematic diagram of this design was illustrated in Fig. 1 . For convenience, the 2 wt%, 3 wt% and 4 wt% Li3PO4 coated samples were named as LRM-2, LRM-3 and LRM-4, respectively. The pristine Li-rich material was named as LRM. 2.2 Materials characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) (Rigaku, Model Ultima IV-185) was used to analyze the crystal structures of the pristine and Li3PO4-coated Li1.2Ni0.2Mn0.6O2 materials. The range of scan angle 2θ was between 10° and 90° and the scan rate was 1 °/min under the Cu Kα radiation source. The morphology and element content of all modified samples were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) system (FEI QUANTA 250) and high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) system (JEM-2100). The valence states of Ni, Mn, P and O elements were characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), which was deployed on a PHI Quantera (ULVAC-PHI, Inc). 2.3 Electrochemical tests The prepared active materials, conductive agent carbon black, and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) were dispersed in N-methylpyrrolidinone (NMP) with a mass ratio of 8:1:1, then the slurry was coated on Al foil. The half-cells were assembled in a glovebox. Lithium metal was used as the anode, the Celgard 2500 was used as the separator, and 1 M LiPF6 dissolved in mixed solvents of ethylene carbonate (EC) and dimethyl carbonate (DMC) with volume ratio 1:1 was used as the electrolyte. In order to detect the electrochemical performance, the galvanostatic charge and discharge were conducted on LAND testing system (Wuhan, China) in the potential range of 2.0–4.8 V. The current density of 250 mA/g was set as 1 C. Electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) of all samples were performed on the CHI660 electrochemical workstation with frequency range from 10−2 Hz to 105 Hz. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Microstructure characterization XRD patterns of all samples are presented in Fig. 2 (a). All the patterns can be indexed to α-NaFeO2 layered structure (R 3 ¯ m space group), being consistent with most Li-rich materials reported in the previous literatures [37]. Due to the presence of LiMn6 superstructure in the transition metal layer, low-intensity diffraction peaks appear between 20° and 25°, which is detected as Li2MnO3 components (C2/m space group) [38]. The distinct peak splits of (006)/(012) and (018)/(110) suggest synthesized materials have high crystallization of the layered structure [39]. The peaks corresponding to Li3PO4 are not found because of the low coating amount. As seen in enlarged Fig. 2(b), (003) and (104) diffraction peaks move toward lower angle after surface coating, particularly evident for the LRM-4 sample. This suggests an increased d-spacing, which may be caused by the permeation of small amounts of PO4 3− (0.238 nm) into the lattice of Li-rich oxide and taking place of some O2− (0.140 nm) positions during the coating process. Additionally, to further investigate the coating material, the pure Li3PO4 was prepared through a same calcination process after mixing with Li2O instead of pristine Li1.2Ni0.2Mn0.6O2. As exhibited in Fig. S1, the XRD results of calcination product is indexed to Li3PO4 with small amount of LiPO3, further indicating the existence of the Li3PO4 coating layer. The surface morphology and particle distribution of these samples were characterized by SEM. As shown in Fig. 3 (a), the well-crystallized pristine LRM exhibits a distinct aggregation with particle diameters around ~300 nm. With the increased Li3PO4 coating amount, the surface of modified samples become rough and the boundaries between the particles are disappeared. However, some nanoparticles can be observed on the LRM-4 surface when the coating content is increased to 4 wt%. This morphology evolution is most likely resulted from the excessive and ununiformly distributed Li3PO4 particles. Moreover, the EDS mappings (Fig. S2) reveal that the P element is distributed in the entire particle, indicating that the uniform Li3PO4 layer is homogeneously coated on the LRM surface. To further illustrate the influence of Li3PO4 coating on the LRM surface, the microstructure of the pristine and modified samples was characterized using TEM. As shown in Fig. S3(a), the pristine material exhibits a typical layered structure with a measured lattice fringe spacing of 0.476 nm, which corresponds to the (003) crystal plane of the layered material [40]. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) figures shown as the inset also confirm the perfect layered structure. After modification, the bulk region still maintains layered structure while it is easy to find the thickness of coating layer is increased with increased coating amount. Notably, the corresponding high-resolution TEM images (Fig. 4 a) reveal that a heterophase Li3PO4 coating layer is interlaced coexist on the whole LRM particle, which is further confirmed by the bright spots (crystalline state, Fig. 4c) and diffuse ring (amorphous state, Fig. 4e) in the fast Fourier transform (FFT) images, respectively. In addition, as shown in Fig. 4(e) and Fig. S4, HRTEM-EDX mapping was also carried out to determine the elemental distribution. Apparently, all elements are uniformly distributed throughout the particles, indicating the successful coating of Li3PO4 on the surface of Li-rich material. The crystallized Li3PO4 will accelerate the interfacial diffusion kinetics of Li+ and the amorphous Li3PO4 can stabilize the crystal structure. This unique combination is expected to improve the electrochemical performance of Li-rich materials at high temperature. XPS was employed to clarify the valence changes of the different elements before and after modification (Fig. 5 and Fig. S5). Three main elements, Ni, Mn, and O, are identified in all the samples, while additional P element are detected on the surface of coated samples, as shown in Fig. S5(a). Fig. S5(b) further demonstrates the distinct features of the P 2p peaks located at 133.25 eV for Li3PO4 coated samples [41]. The intensity of the P 2p peak increases as the coating amount increases. These results indicate that Li3PO4 was successfully coated on the Li-rich cathode material. Besides, the split peaks of Ni 2p 3/2 (854.6 eV for Ni2+, 855.5 eV for Ni3+) in Fig. S5(c) show a similar proportion in all samples, indicating that the coating process does not change the chemical state of Ni [42]. Additionally, detailed information of Mn 2p spectra is exhibited in Fig. 5(a). The Mn 2p 3/2 can be split into two different peaks located at 642.4 eV (Mn4+) and 641.4 eV (Mn3+), proving mixed +4 and +3 valence states of Mn ions [43]. For LRM-2 sample, it can be observed that the relative concentration ratios of Mn4+/Mn3+ decreases correspondingly from 7.76 to 4.74, which implies that some Mn4+ ions on the surface were reduced after modification. In Fig. 5(b), O 1s peaks of pristine LRM located at 529.4 eV and 531.3 eV correspond to the lattice oxygen (O–M–O) and oxygen vacancies, respectively [44]. Notably, after Li3PO4 surface modification, the later peak area obviously enhances, indicating oxygen deficiency are formed in modified samples. Besides, an extra peak located at 529.9 eV is close to the O 1s binding energy of Li3PO4. Similar with P 2p spectrum, the proportion of this peak area gradually increases from 5.23% to 6.32% as the coating amount increases, which further demonstrates that Li3PO4 is successfully coated on the surface of the materials [29]. Combining with the XPS results of Mn, we believe that some surface Mn4+ ions were reduced together with the formation of O deficiency during the coating process. This change can be regarded as the chemical activation of Li2MnO3, which can contribute to improve the initial coulombic efficiency of Li-rich material. 3.2 Electrochemical performance Through this unique surface coating engineering, the amorphous/crystalline Li3PO4 coated LRM is expected to obtain superior electrochemical properties. Fig. 6 (a) depicts the initial charge and discharge plots of all samples at 0.1 C under 30 °C. The charging profiles of all the samples consist of two regions during the initial charge process. The first slope corresponds to Li+ extraction from the lattice of LiMn0.5Ni0.5O2 is discovered below 4.5 V, while the other one is a long platform at 4.5 V, which relates to activation of Li2MnO3 [45]. The specific capacities of pristine LRM, LRM-2, and LRM-3 are 264, 258, and 257 mAh/g, respectively, while LRM-4 exhibits the lowest discharge capacity of 252 mAh/g. The decreased capacity should ascribe to the wrapping of high content Li3PO4 coating layer with electrochemical inactivity. In addition, the cycle performance was also evaluated at 1 C for 100 cycles. As exhibited in Fig. 6(b), the capacity retention of LRM-3 was improved slightly, compared to that of pristine LRM at 30 °C. Given that, Li3PO4 with amorphous/crystalline heterophase is generally considered as the best-performing coating material at elevated temperature, these electrochemical performances were further explored at a strict condition (55 °C). As presented in Fig. 6(c), all the modified LRM materials deliver a high discharge capacity about 290 mAh/g at 55 °C with greatly improved initial coulombic efficiency (ICE). By contrast, the pristine LRM exhibits an ICE of 80% only, which is much lower than that of LRM-3 (89%) and LRM-4 (92%). The higher ICE is due to more oxygen deficiency formed on the surface during the coating process as we discussed in the XPS section, which can significantly decrease the scale of oxygen loss and shorten the 4.5 V charge platform. Fig. 6(d) compares 1 C charge/discharge profiles upon 100 cycles at 55 °C. The capacity retentions of modified samples are greatly improved. The discharge capacities after 100 cycles are 154.5, 180.9, 192.9 and 168.6 mAh/g for LRM, LRM-2, LRM-3 and LRM-4, respectively. In the selected charge-discharge curve profiles recorded at 1 C (Fig. 6e and f), we can see that the specific capacity decreased severely after 60 cycles for pristine LRM. On the contrary, in the 90th cycle, there is almost 140 mAh/g above 3.0 V can be observed in LRM-3 sample. From the above, we can conclude that the amorphous/crystalline Li3PO4 coating layer can stabilize the crystal structure of Li-rich cathode material significantly, especially at elevated temperature. As far as we all known, such electrochemical performances are comparable to that reported in previous literature (Table S1). Considering the commercial application of Li-rich cathode materials, voltage decay has more severe impact on energy density than capacity decay. The initial average discharge voltage of all samples is similar, as shown in Fig. 7 (a). The average voltage of pristine LRM can maintain 3.35 V after 50 cycles, while it rapidly degrades to 2.88 V after 100 cycles at 55 °C, displaying a serious voltage decay during prolonged cycling, which is a typical phenomenon of lithium rich materials. On the contrary, the LRM-3 presents a relieved voltage decay from 3.49 V to 3.19 V during 100 cycles. The voltage decay is 2.99 mV per cycle for LRM-3 sample, which is about half of that of pristine LRM (5.96 mV per cycle). Similarly, the discharge-voltage decay of LRM-3 sample at 30 °C also shows a mitigating effect with only 1.64 mV per cycle, as presented in Fig. S6(a). In addition, the normalized charge/discharge curves, which more intuitively display the capacity change and voltage attenuation during long cycling at elevated temperature, are displayed in Fig. 7(b) and (c). The normalized curves of pristine LRM illustrate an apparently greater alteration than LRM-3 in the voltage region of 2.8–3.5 V, revealing that the amorphous/crystalline Li3PO4 coating layer has a significant effect on the suppression of the voltage decay. This voltage decay tendency is recognized with differential capacity (dQ/dV) curves depicted in Fig. 8 (a) and (b). During the initial discharging process, the two major reduction peaks at 3.75 V (R1) and 3.25 V (R2) are considered as the redox couple of Ni4+/3+/2+ + and Mn4+/3+, contributing to most of the specific capacity. Apparently, the reduction peak R1 for coated sample LRM-3 shifts continuously and becomes broadened upon cycling, but it disappears as for pristine LRM. Meanwhile, the reduction peak R2 for pristine LRM moves to lower voltage about 2.75 V with a significantly changing shape and decreased intensity. However, the movement of the reduction peak R2 for LRM-3 sample is much smaller. The movement of the reduction peak R2 is caused by the formation of spinel phase essentially. Therefore, these results clearly indicate that the amorphous/crystalline Li3PO4 surface coating can greatly stabilize the crystal structure and effectively suppress the voltage fade upon delithiation/lithiation process. To further evaluate the interfacial electrochemistry and reaction kinetics, EIS was performed after different cycles. Fig. 8(c,d) and Fig. S7 exhibit the Nyquist plots and the corresponding equivalent circuit. All the Nyquist plots are divided into a semicircle in the high frequency and a slope in the low frequency region. In the equivalent circuit, R s represents ohmic resistance, R ct corresponds to charge transfer resistance between electrolyte and electrode interface, CPE means double layer capacitance, and Ws is Warburg impedance related to the lithium ion diffusion in the electrode [46]. Table S2 exhibits the fitting results of R ct parameters of all the samples at different selected cycles. Obviously, the value of R ct for LRM rapidly increases from 41.95 Ω (25th) to 361.8 Ω (100th), while that of LRM-3 (211.1 Ω at 100th) performs a tardy tendency. This promoted charge transfer kinetic is attribute to the good ionic conductivity of crystalline Li3PO4. Meanwhile, the Nyquist impedance plot of LRM-3 exhibits a bigger slope in the low frequency region, which mainly attributes to the fact that amorphous Li3PO4 inhibits the occurrence of interfacial side reactions and reduces impurities in the electrodes. Therefore, the amorphous/crystalline Li3PO4 coating layer can sharply decrease the resistance of Li-rich cathode, thus benefiting its electrochemical performance. The crystal structure and surface morphology changes of the Li-rich materials after 100 cycles at 1 C were conducted by XRD and HRTEM characterizations. As revealed in the XRD patterns (Fig. S8), the characteristic peak intensity of LRM-3 is much higher than pristine LRM, further confirming the well-maintaining of layered structure for modified sample. Furthermore, the crystal structure of the pristine LRM in Fig. 9 (a) shows a significant structural degradation from a layered to spinel phase in prolonged cycling, which is the main origin of voltage decay at elevated temperature. Fortunately, after the surface coating engineering modification, the layered structure of LRM-3 is well reserved as exhibited in Fig. 9(c), with much less formation of spinel phase. More importantly, the Li3PO4 coating layer with crystalline and amorphous can reserve well, the FFT images corresponding to the enlarged region of d and e in Fig. 9(b) also can further demonstrate. This discovery not only suggests the inherent stability of Li3PO4, but also ensures this special heterophase coating layer can always play the synergistic effect on the host Li-rich material during the long cycling. 4 Conclusions In summary, surface coating engineering modified Li-rich materials were successfully synthesized by a facile wet chemical method, which ensures the uniform coating of amorphous/crystalline Li3PO4 on the surface of Li1.2Ni0.2Mn0.6O2. As expected, the special heterophase Li3PO4 coating strategy can counter capacity fading (from 64.78 to 76.46% after 100 cycles at 1 C under 55 °C) and voltage decay (from 5.96 to 2.99 mV per cycle). The improved electrochemical performance can be attributed to the synergetic effect of amorphous/crystalline Li3PO4 coating layer. On the one hand, the amorphous Li3PO4 can prevent the host cathode from electrolyte erosion and greatly inhibit the surface structural transformation. On the other hand, the crystalline Li3PO4 with superior ionic conductivity can simultaneously facilitate Li+ diffusion and enhance the reaction kinetics. Additionally, part of PO4 3− permeated into the lattice of Li-rich material. The strong covalent bond of PO4 3− polyanion and accompanied formation of oxygen vacancies can retard the oxygen release from the surface, resulting in alleviated structure transformation and voltage decay in prolonged cycling at elevated temperature. Therefore, we believe that this unique structure configuration of amorphous/crystalline Li3PO4 coating can provide a new prospect to overcome the application drawbacks of Li-rich cathode materials at high temperature. coredata.dc:description: Li-rich layered oxides have become one of the most concerned cathode materials for high-energy lithium-ion batteries, but they still suffer from poor cycling stability and detrimental voltage decay, especially at elevated temperature. Herein, we proposed a surface heterophase coating engineering based on amorphous/crystalline Li3PO4 to address these issues for Li-rich layered oxides via a facile wet chemical method. The heterophase coating layer combines the advantages of physical barrier effect achieved by amorphous Li3PO4 with facilitated Li+ diffusion stemmed from crystalline Li3PO4. Consequently, the modified Li1.2Ni0.2Mn0.6O2 delivers higher initial coulombic efficiency of 92% with enhanced cycling stability at 55 °C (192.9 mAh/g after 100 cycles at 1 C). More importantly, the intrinsic voltage decay has been inhibited as well, i.e. the average potential drop per cycle decreases from 5.96 mV to 2.99 mV. This surface heterophase coating engineering provides an effective strategy to enhance the high-temperature electrochemical performances of Li-rich layered oxides and guides the direction of surface modification strategies for cathode materials in the future.

coredata.dc:title: Enhanced high-temperature performance of Li-rich layered oxide via surface heterophase coating
